Title: Charges dropped against second man arrested at motel by Venice police
Summary:
Miscommunication led to resisting arrest and marijuana possession charges against 46-year-old cancer patient

VENICE ‚Äî Charges have been dropped against a second man arrested by Venice police Dec. 21 in an incident defense attorneys say involved excessive force and poor judgement by police.

John Fegley, a 46-year-man with stage-four cancer, was a paid guest at Motel 6 in Venice when hotel staff fingered him as a crime suspect ‚Äî described as white man with a black hoodie and a dog ‚Äî who was accused of burglary, along with another man.

According to a police report, Venice police officers confronted Fegley ‚Äî without his dog Loki ‚Äî leaving his motel room to go to work. Officers told him to put his hands behind his back, and he replied, "Wait."

But seconds later, without listening to what he had to say, police grabbed Fegley's arms, cut his feet from under him, and used force to take him to the ground.

Fegley shouted, "No, no, no," and told officers he has cancer.

Police later learned Fegley was a registered guest at Motel 6, which was corroborated by multiple witnesses at the scene. Ethan Waters, 19, who had also been taken down forcefully by police moments earlier, was detained in a nearby squad car.

Both men were charged with resisting arrest and, in addition, Fegley was additionally charged with misdemeanor possession of marijuana and drug paraphernalia for having a pipe in his pocket.

On Thursday, the State Attorney's Office dropped all charges against Fegley after an investigation determined no burglary was committed.

"The State determines the miscommunication the registered guest shared with the motel led to the call to police. Considering the police investigation revealed that the defendant did not commit a burglary, the State finds that the interest of justice are not served by continued prosecution in this matter and the charges against this defendant are dropped."

The Herald-Tribune contacted Fegley Thursday, who was working and unaware his charges had been dropped.

Two police reports describing Fegley's altercation with officers told conflicting stories about their initial contact with the 46-year-old man.

Officer James Atwell, who helped arrest Waters, stated he saw a suspect ‚Äî identified as Fegley ‚Äî leave a hotel room and enter the parking lot. Another report by Sergeant Alek Gregoire stated he was told that two individuals committed a burglary and the second subject was in the area hiding.

Gregoire walked the parking lot until he saw a man fitting the description of the suspect ‚Äî a white male, with a black hoodie and a dog ‚Äî come around the corner of the motel, "where he had been concealing himself."

Fegley walked quickly to a white Pontiac parked in the motel lot, Gregoire said, who clarified the description of the second subject with dispatch. He met Fegley, who was earlier walking his dog, and said, "by his demeanor (walking quickly)(prior concealment) and his fearful look towards us, we had probable cause to believe he was the second suspect."

Atwell and Gregoire asked him to stop, which he did, and asked him if he had a dog.

"Knowing this was the suspect we were looking for, I immediately grabbed the suspect's right arm, in order to secure him, while Officer Atwell who had just come up went to his right side," according to Gregoire, who stated Fegley was trying to evade detainment and a flight risk due to the nature of the crime.

"I automatically thought my dog did something wrong," Fegley told the Herald-Tribune Thursday. "My dog was on a leash. They said I was guilty and beat the hell out of me.

"We rented the rooms."

After he was detained, Fegley said hotel staff told police that he was a registered guest.

But in private conversations captured by a police audio and video recording system called "Watchguard," staff told officers that the men were working together and could be under the influence of drugs.

Fegley was staying in the room with a Motel 6 employee.

"You guys are doing this all wrong," Fegley said he told police. "Twenty years ago this would never have happened. You would have asked what I was doing and I told you the truth, I was walking my dog and leave me alone.

"They told me I'm lucky my dog wasn't with me or they would have shot him. I was just literally walking my dog."

Fegley said he has been a manager at a Kentucky Fried Chicken for the nine years. He has Hodgkin's lymphoma and is undergoing chemotherapy.

"I was in tears. I couldn‚Äôt believe this happened to me," Fegley said. "These officers ‚Äî they way they handled it was unprofessional. They handled it like they were on SWAT. They had no right to disrespect me or Ethan."

Fegley said he had never met Waters before.

Michael Barfield, a paralegal and president of the ACLU, has asked Venice Police Chief Tom Mattmuller to put the involved officers on paid leave, while they are investigated for filing a false police report, battery, excessive force, and false imprisonment. He supports the State Attorney's decision to abandon charges.

"These individuals were truly innocent for any crimes; I'm glad that chapter is done," Barfield said. "We still need to know how something like this could happen. The description of the charges seems like an afterthought. I think there should be a criminal investigation into whether those statements were false."

Barfield does not think the Venice Police Department should conduct the investigation into their own officer's alleged misconduct.

"It's too small of an agency to investigate its own in a high profile matter like this," he said. "They should ask the Sheriff's Office or Florida Department of Law Enforcement to conduct the investigation."
Address: 1777 Main St, Sarasota, FL 34236, USA

Title: Milton High grads Watson, Weekley continue PGA Tour‚Äôs amazing storyline
Summary:
CLOSE WATCH: Bubba Watson reflects on PGA memories Bill Vilona, Special to PNJ

Though five years apart in age, Bubba Watson and Boo Weekley have a commonality in professional golf extending well beyond their country boy first names and growing up in the same community.

They are self-taught players, who rose from frequent rounds at Tanglewood Golf Course, often with Heath Slocum -- the third connection of the Milton High-to-PGA Tour improbable journey -- into winning in golf‚Äôs highest, world competitive arena.

Thirteen years after Watson and Weekley first competed together on the PGA Tour, both realize their golf background and longevity is something that may never been seen again.

Buy Photo Bubba Watson tees off on the 11th hole last Friday during the second round of the Zurich Classic at TPC-Louisiana in New Orleans. (Photo: Bill Vilona)

‚ÄúYou could say places like LA, or Dallas, or other cities with a lot of people, a lot of more affluent people in golf that something like this might happen there,‚Äù said Watson, who turned 40 in November, following a 2018 season where he won three PGA Tour events. ‚ÄúBut when your talking about East Milton (Boo‚Äôs neighborhood) and Bagdad (Bubba‚Äôs home), it‚Äôs going to be very hard to beat that.‚Äù

So fitting the duo finished 30 minutes apart last Friday on the 18th hole at the Tournament Players Club-Louisiana, following a rain-delayed first round of the Zurich Classic in New Orleans. A round that started 20-plus hours earlier for both players.

But here they were, two players from the same high school, who played the same Pensacola area public courses, together among a field from the world on the PGA Tour last week in New Orleans.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs what the Good Lord planned for us,‚Äù said Weekley, 45, whose spirits have been tested the past two years with elbow surgery and removal of a cancerous cyst from his shoulder. ‚Äú(God) had a plan for all of us, Heath included. It was a matter of how we handle it and how we do it.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt believe I was a golfer growing up. I was a hunter and fisherman and I was going to do something else. Bubba knew he was going to be a golfer. Heath knew he was going to be a golfer. So they kinda both inspired me to be a little better than I was.‚Äù

Weekley and Slocum, 45, who lives in Alpharetta, Ga., and last played a full PGA Tour schedule in 2015, were on the same Milton Panthers boys golf team coached by now-athletic director Murry Rutledge.

Watson was 12 years old when both were Milton High seniors.

‚ÄúThey were my idols growing up,‚Äù said Watson, now co-owner of the Pensacola Blue Wahoos and with a PGA Tour career of 12 wins, including two Masters Tournament victories that quality him for World Golf Hall of Fame consideration.

He reflected on the path last Friday at the Zurich Classic which included two busloads of 75 Blue Wahoos‚Äô season-ticket holders, sponsors and front office stay traveling to see him.

‚ÄúI was young, watching them, learning from them and seeing how they were doing it,‚Äù said Watson, who teamed with J.B. Holmes to make the cut and finished tied for 34th. ‚ÄúI wanted to be like them. I wanted to play on (Milton) team, then continue on in golf and hopefully be a pro.

‚ÄúAnd now, when you look and see that all three of us have won at least three times on (PGA) Tour and we all played in the 2008 Masters‚Ä¶ and we lived in Milton (Slocum), East Milton and Bagdad‚Ä¶. you add all that up, it‚Äôs pretty remarkable.‚Äù

As Watson said, it‚Äôs something that might be possible in a major city, but likely from the same private club. That‚Äôs not the case with this group.

Boo and Bubba both learned the game from their fathers, but neither went off to private golf academies or traveled across the globe to play in junior golf tournaments. Slocum‚Äôs father, Jack, was a PGA of America teaching pro and former mini-tour player.

‚ÄúFor me, all of a sudden, it just kinda clicked,‚Äù said Weekley, who played with friend Colt Knost at the Zurich Classic, but the duo didn‚Äôt make the cut. ‚ÄúAnd I got the right breaks at the right time. I have been healthy enough to stay out there and play the game.‚Äù

After Weekley missed all last season to recover from the tendinitis and cancer surgery, he has limited playing status on the PGA Tour, but is fully exempt on the tour-sanctioned, Web.com Tour.

He finished tied for 25th two weeks ago at the Heritage Classic in Hilton Head, S.C., an event Weekley won two of this three PGA Tour events. He‚Äôs planning to play as much golf as his body allows. His oldest son, Parker, is now 17 and ‚Äútaller than I am,‚Äù Weekley said, and a junior at Milton.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm still trying to get my mind wrapped around the actual grind again,‚Äù Weekley said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre still knocking off the cobwebs to a certain degree. I get out there practicing, and I say, ‚ÄòMan, why am I doing this?‚Äô My body is not feeling as good.

‚ÄúIt is hard to get myself motivated sometimes. Some days, it‚Äôs like going through the motions like slinging a hammer. It‚Äôs just bam, bam‚Ä¶ it gets old after awhile.

‚ÄúBeing able to come back here (on PGA Tour), I wasn‚Äôt sure. But at least I knew I would go out and try it one more time on the Web.com. I haven‚Äôt played well (on Web), but I have out here (PGA Tour). I feel I can compete out there.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to try and do it as long as I can do it.‚Äù

For both Weekley and Watson, it‚Äôs been a journey that has defied odds.

Bill Vilona is a retired Pensacola News Journal sports columnist and current senior writer for Pensacola Blue Wahoos/Studer55. He can be reached at bvilona@bluewahoos.com.
Address: 101 E Romana St, Pensacola, FL 32502, USA

Title: Judge gives no jail time to bus driver who raped girl; thousands sign petition to have him removed
Summary:
Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. Shane Piche.

(AP/WFLA) - A petition calling for the removal of a New York judge who sentenced a bus driver to probation, after the man pleaded guilty to raping a 14-year-old girl has more than 60,000 signatures.

"Judge James McClusky just let a child rapist off with a slap on the wrist. Remove him from his position immediately for his blatant disregard for survivors of sexual assault," wrote the petition's author, Shaunna Thomas.

McClusky drew ire last week when he sentenced Shane Piche to 10 years of probation.

RELATED:

Bus driver who pleaded guilty to raping 14-year-old girl gets no jail time

The 26-year-old was accused of raping the teenager at his residence in Watertown, New York, last summer. Piche, who was a bus driver in the victim‚Äôs school district, pleaded guilty to third-degree rape in February.

Piche also was required to register as a Level 1 sex offender, the lowest of three categories based on the risk of another offense. Three orders of protection were issued and Piche was ordered not to be left alone with anyone under the age of 17.

The sentencing drew national media attention and harsh criticism. Twitter users posted the phone number and address of McClusky‚Äôs chambers in Watertown.

‚ÄúThe Judge‚Äôs chambers have received numerous vitriolic calls regarding the case, the vast majority from out of State, by individuals who know nothing about the facts and circumstances of the case, thanks to social media,‚Äù state court spokesman Lucian Chalfen wrote in an email.

Chalfen said the judge was ‚Äúwell within‚Äù the sentencing range for this type of negotiated plea conviction. The maximum state prison time he could have received would have been from 1 1/3 to 4 years, he said.

Jefferson County chief assistant district attorney Patricia Dziuba said all parties acted within the parameters set by law and that the prosecutor handling the case sought up to six months of jail time along with probation, supervision and treatment. She declined to criticize the judge‚Äôs sentence.

Piche didn‚Äôt make a statement during his sentencing.

Calls seeking comment were left Tuesday with McCluskey and Piche‚Äôs attorney, Eric Swartz.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôll be a felon for the rest of his life. He‚Äôs on the sex offender registry for a long time,‚Äù Swartz told television station WWNY of Watertown.

The station said a victim impact statement given to them by the victim‚Äôs mother read, ‚ÄúI wish Shane Piche would have received time in jail for the harm he caused to my child. He took something from my daughter she will never get back and has caused her to struggle with depression and anxiety.‚Äù

Thomas' petition has been circulating for less than two days and already has over 60,000 signatures. The goal is to reach 75,000.

The petition can be found here.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: Pasco deputies: Woman posted man's nude photos, asked for $500 to take them down
Summary:
- A Pasco County woman is accused of using nude photos of a man to try and extort money from him.

Deputies say she managed to change the man‚Äôs social media passwords and then posted the pictures on his accounts.

Pasco County deputies say Breyanna Helen Dean used shame and embarrassment to try and manipulate a man into giving her $500.

‚ÄúThese photos were pictures of his genitalia that he took,‚Äù attorney Denis DeVlaming explained.

Investigators aren‚Äôt saying what Dean‚Äôs relationship is to the man or his name, but they arrested Dean‚Äôs ex-boyfriend, Christian Belanger-Leppinen, for breaking into her home around the same time she posted the photos.

Continue reading below

Deputies say Dean found the pictures on an old phone. That‚Äôs when she apparently devised the scheme and contacted the man demanding payment if he wanted the photos to be deleted.

‚ÄúThis is the first case where I‚Äôve seen a woman doing it to a man,‚Äù said DeVlaming.

Dean‚Äôs charges stem from the threat of extortion, which is a felony. Some call it ‚Äòsextortion.‚Äô

But even without extortion, the simple act of sharing nude photos of someone else, without permission, will get you in trouble.

‚ÄúIf you send it into the internet without the consent of the person of whose picture you‚Äôre sending, you‚Äôve committed a crime in Florida,‚Äù DeVlaming explained.

That crime is sexual cyber harassment. A first offense is a misdemeanor. Do it again and it‚Äôs a felony.

A 2013 study found more than 55% of young adults have sent nude selfies. Law enforcement says it‚Äôs leading to more crimes like this.

‚ÄúIt might not even be a monetary request, it might be, ‚ÄòYou‚Äôll have to meet me here or do this or do that.‚Äô And it‚Äôs going to happen more and more,‚Äù DeVlaming said.

Breyanna Dean is home now, released on a $10,000 bond.
Address: 3213 W Kennedy Blvd, Tampa, FL 33609, USA

Title: Friends and family remember Fort Pierce father killed after crashing into house
Summary:
Michael Smith (right) with his son Mason Smith (left). Michael Smith died Tuesday after running a stop sign and crashing into a house. (Photo: COURTESY OF ASHLEY SMITH)

Michael Smith loved three things in life, which were his two sons and fishing, his sister Ashley Smith said.

"He loved hunting and fishing with my dad," she said. "He just loved being outside and doing stuff like that."

Michael Smith died Tuesday after running a stop sign and crashing into a house. Smith, 26, of Fort Pierce, left behind two sons, Michael, 5, and Mason, 2.

"He would do anything for his kids," she said.

More: Fort Pierce man killed after crashing into house

Smith was driving northbound on Birch Drive, approaching Bradley Street at 4:32 a.m. Tuesday. After he ran a stop sign, he failed to negotiate a curve and crashed into the garage of a house on Birch Drive, according to a Florida Highway Patrol news release.

Smith's vehicle, a 2009 Ford Explorer, crashed through the garage and struck a 2017 Jeep Wrangler and two motorcycles, which were parked there.

Michael Smith (right) with his son Michael Smith Junior (left.) Michael Smith died on Tuesday after a crash. His sister, Ashley Smith, said he would do anything for his two sons. (Photo: COURTESY OF ASHLEY SMITH)

Tyler Cheatham said he was a senior member of Future Farmers of America, a student organization for people interested in agriculture, and met Michael through the program.

"He liked animals and he loved kids," he said. "It's crazy, I was just talking to him a few weeks ago."

Cheatham said Smith had "his heart on his sleeve and didn't hold anything against anyone."

Brandon Burton, who has known Michael since the two were teens, said he remembers Michael coming to his home with Michael's father and talking about the deer or hog the two had caught that day.

"We'd just sit around the house and drink beer and cook (the game)," Burton said. "He was really into fishing and hunting."

More: 29-year-old Stuart man dead after thrown out of truck during crash in Indiantown

For a profession, Ashley Smith said her brother built boats with their father at Pursuit Boats, 3901 St. Lucie Boulevard in Fort Pierce.

Burton said one of Smith's strong suits was making people laugh.

"He was really outgoing," he said. "if anybody was feeling down, he'd always go to them and cheer them up."

Ashley Smith said her younger brother had "a heart of gold."

"He'd give you anything if he had it," she said. "He's got a good sense of humor and was very caring."

Title: Frontier sends refund to man who overpaid $15,000
Summary:
RUSKIN, Fla. (WFLA) - Jim Hohler finally has his nearly $15,000 internet bill overpayment back after a little intervention from Better Call Behnken.

"Right away that happened. Twenty-four hours later, we got one," Hohler said.

"He just needed to confirm I didn't stop payment on the other. Twenty-four hours later I got the other, close to $15,000."

He admits, the first mistake was all him. The mistake was an epic misplacement of a decimal point, an error he likely won't live down any time soon.

His two payments to Frontier Communication, one of $68.99 and one of $79.99, turned into $6,899 and $7,999, for a grand total of nearly $15,000.

Giving his money away was easy, but getting it back turned into a headache.

After nearly three weeks, he knew he'd Better Call Behnken.

"It wouldn't have happened on my own. It really wouldn't have. My other other recourse was to just close my account and wait for the refund to come that way because I just couldn't get through to them at all."

He's learned the painful lesson of double checking online bill payments.

Frontier sent this statement when first contacted by 8 On Your Side.

"We apologize for the concern this has caused our customer and have a senior customer service representative in direct contact to keep him informed on the status of the refunds.‚Äù

They quickly processed the checks and Hohler had them within days.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: Driver sentenced to 5 years for hitting 8 Navy servicemen while drunk
Summary:
A 58-year-old man was sentenced Tuesday for hitting eight Navy servicemen from Naval Air Station Pensacola in his vehicle in 2017 while drunk behind the wheel on Perdido Key Drive.

Eric Watt pleaded guilty to two counts of DUI with serious bodily injury and two counts of DUI damage to property or person in February.

Eric Watt (Photo: Courtesy of the Escambia County Jail)

On April 29, 2017, eight flight students from NAS Pensacola were walking home along Perdido Key Drive when they were hit from behind by a car driven by the Watt. The crash caused serious bodily injury to six of the eight victims and they were taken to several area hospitals. An investigation determined that Watts was under the influence of alcohol and marijuana at the time of the crash.

On Tuesday, Watt was sentenced to five years in state prison, followed by two years of community control and an additional five years probation, according to Assistant State Attorney Greg Marcille.

Community control is an enhanced version of probation that is much more restrictive, Marcille said.

A witness told authorities they observed the crash at about 8 p.m. and helped the eight victims who had been struck by Watt's Infiniti, according to a Florida Highway Patrol incident report.

When Florida Highway Patrol troopers arrived, they reportedly smelled alcohol on Watt and noticed his eyes were bloodshot, according to Watt‚Äôs arrest report.

Troopers administered two breathalyzer tests, and Watts blew 0.088 and 0.093. The legal limit is 0.08.

One witness told authorities they positioned themselves in front of Watt‚Äôs vehicle to stop him from driving away from the accident site, an incident report stated.

The eight men who were injured:

Jordan Lo, 24

Kevin Park, 24

Steven Parsons, 26

Christian Martinez, age unknown

Jerome Wallar, age unknown

Brandon Nunez, age unknown

Christopher Martinez, 25

Travis Hehman, 23

Colin Warren-Hicks can be reached at colinwarrenhicks@pnj.com or 850-435-8680.

Title: Florida mom credits flight crew, passengers with saving baby's life during seizure
Summary:
Instagram photo courtesy: Janay Flowers Instagram photo courtesy: Janay Flowers

- High up in the clouds, a mother had a terrifying experience when her baby had seizure during their flight from Tampa to Dallas.

On April 25, Janay Flowers departed from Tampa International Airport on American Airlines Flight 607 with her 11-month-old daughter, Nevaeh. Ten minutes before landing in Dallas, Nevaeh spiked a fever and had a febrile seizure. Flowers told FOX 13 she didn‚Äôt know if her daughter would survive.

‚ÄúI started to freak out,‚Äù she recalled. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe this is happening ‚Äì not my baby. This can‚Äôt be happening.‚Äù

Flowers started screaming out for help. That‚Äôs when several passengers ‚Äì including a nurse ‚Äì and flight attendant rushed to help. The nurse, named Tiffany, turned Naveah on her side and pulled her tongue out of her mouth to clear her airway. A second passenger, Alvin, assisted.

"All of these people worked diligently to cool my baby down while she was having a seizure," she wrote in an Instagram post. "One man went to the front of the plane to ensure that the EMS was at the gate as soon as we landed. Another man got an oxygen tank and administered it to Nevaeh. Another man was taking her pulse. As soon as our plane landed, we all rushed to the front of the plane while they grabbed all of my belongings. One man carried my baby, one man kept thumping her foot to make her cry."

Continue reading below

Flowers said she felt helpless as she watched but tried to comfort her daughter by singing, ‚ÄúYou Are My Sunshine,‚Äù until they finally landed and paramedics took over. Later, Flowers said she learned Naveah had stopped breathing and had a temperature of 104 degrees. Prior to the incident, she said her baby never had a seizure.

Doctors said Naveah appears to be healthy and there were no underlying issues, Flowers explained.

‚ÄúI literally don‚Äôt have the words for all the emotions I was feeling‚Ä¶all of the emotions I am feeling now,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so grateful she is still here. I know it‚Äôs God that she is still here. He put everybody into place to help me save this baby.‚Äù

Flowers managed to make contact with Tiffany and Alvin through Facetime, and invited them to attend Naveah‚Äôs first birthday party next month.
Address: 3213 W Kennedy Blvd, Tampa, FL 33609, USA

Title: Man smashes windows at Cabo's restaurant, later apologizes
Summary:
Buy Photo Mike Ferrara, owner of Cabo's Island Grill and Bar, stands outside the restaurant, where a customer smashed large storefront windows Sunday night. (Photo: Alicia Devine/Tallahassee Democrat)

Mike Ferrara was home watching ‚ÄúGame of Thrones‚Äù on Sunday night when he got a call about drama of a different kind at his restaurant, Cabo‚Äôs Island Grill & Bar.

As the long-awaited battle of Winterfell began on the hit HBO show, Ferrara learned an unexpected skirmish had just happened at his restaurant on Apalachee Parkway.

He went down and was shocked by what he saw ‚Äî holes smashed in the restaurant's big storefront windows and glass knocked out of the front doors. There were blood stains on the windows, which were somehow still intact.

Buy Photo Large storefront windows at Cabo's vandalized by an unruly patron are held together by tape for now. It could take several days for repairs to be complete. (Photo: Alicia Devine/Tallahassee Democrat)

It all happened, Ferrara said, after a man in the lounge had a few beers and started acting "really weird." A bartender asked him to leave, but the man shoved him and got into it with another customer, at which point the disturbance spilled outside. The unruly bar patron punched the customer before taking out his anger on the windows.

‚ÄúApparently he walked down here with a knife in his hand and punched out one, two, three, four, five windows and a door,‚Äù Ferrara said. ‚ÄúIt was pretty obvious ... that he cut his hand pretty badly. I can‚Äôt imagine a rational person (doing that).‚Äù

Buy Photo Closeup photo of a damaged window at Cabo's restaurant on Tuesday, April 30, 2019. (Photo: Alicia Devine/Tallahassee Democrat)

Someone called the police before the man left the lounge. By the time officers arrived, the man was gone.

But the story took an unexpected turn the next day. Ferrara, who posted photos of the damage on Facebook, got a call from the man responsible for the damage. He was "profoundly apologetic," Ferrara said, and promised to help cover the repairs, which could cost thousands. The man called again Tuesday to arrange a first payment.

Buy Photo Andy Miller with Miller Glass scrapes excess glass from the front door at Cabo's restaurant on Tuesday, April 30, 2019. (Photo: Alicia Devine/Tallahassee Democrat)

The restaurant, normally closed on Monday, reopened as usual on Tuesday, though a row of boots along the damaged windows is closed for now. The front door got fixed, but it could be next week before the windows are replaced.

No arrest has been made and the case remains open, said Officer Damon Miller, spokesman for the Tallahassee Police Department. Ferrara, who finally watched that ‚ÄúGame of Thrones‚Äù episode on Monday, doesn‚Äôt want to pursue charges as long as the man helps pay for the damage.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just trying to be a nice guy about it,‚Äù Ferrara said. ‚ÄúHe showed remorse, and I believe him. A lot of people said this was out of character for this guy. I‚Äôm going to give him the benefit of the doubt.‚Äù

Contact Jeff Burlew at jburlew@tallahassee.com or follow @JeffBurlew on Twitter.

Read or Share this story: https://www.tallahassee.com/story/news/local/2019/04/30/man-smashes-windows-cabos-restaurant-later-apologizes/3626866002/
Address: 277 N Magnolia Dr, Tallahassee, FL 32301, USA

Title: Pasco man gets drunk, tells cops he's Jason Bourne
Summary:
Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. Pinellas County Sheriff's Office

TAMPA (WFLA) - A St. Petersburg man was thrown out of the Barbara S. Ponce library for being drunk was arrested after telling police his name was Jason Bourne, authorities said.

According to Pinellas Park police, Jonathan Chapman, 45 was under the influence of alcohol and refused to leave the library despite multiple requests from library staff that he go, according to the report.

When officers confronted Chapman he told police his name was "Jason Bourne" the name of the character of Robert Ludlum‚Äôs book series, and a phony Social Security number, the report said.

Chapman was arrested for obstruction by disguise, and resisting an officer without violence.

Title: Jacksonville man injured in mishap while working on car
Summary:
JACKSONVILLE, Fla. - A 64-year-old Jacksonville man suffered life-threatening injuries Monday afternoon when the car was working on rolled forward and pinned him underneath.

The incident happened shortly before 2 p.m. at the Woodlake Park Apartments on San Jose Boulevard near Sunbeam Road in the Mandarin neighborhood, according to the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office.

The Sheriff's Office said the man and his adult son were working on a Toyota Corolla but were not using jacks to prop the vehicle up at the time of what appears to be an accident.

When police and paramedics arrived, the man was trapped. Once he was extricated, paramedics rushed him to Memorial Hospital with life-threatening injuries, according to police.

Title: Pensacola man charged with shooting a victim in back
Summary:
A Pensacola man is in jail after allegedly shooting another man in the back while attempting to collect a debt.

John Randell Waller Jr., 22, was charged with aggravated battery with a deadly weapon and firing a weapon in public Thursday in connection with a shooting in West Pensacola.

Around 3 p.m., Escambia County Sheriff's Office deputies were called to the first block of Kennington Drive in reference to a shooting victim, according to Waller's arrest report. Deputies found a male victim on the ground with an acquaintance applying pressure to a gunshot wound in his back.

Crime in Santa Rosa County: SRSO: Florida man brings drugs to a drug bust, gets himself busted

Drug arrest: Florida man on meth attacks mattress while looking for man 'hiding inside,' police say

The victim reported that he could not move his lower limbs, and he was ultimately transported to Baptist Hospital for treatment.

According to a witness statement in the report, Waller came over to the residence looking for someone who owed him money. The report indicates Waller hid in the backyard until the victim arrived. When the victim showed up, saw Waller and tried to run away, he was shot in the back, the document alleges.

John Waller Jr. (Photo: Escambia County Jail)

Deputies were able to find Waller at his residence and take him into custody.

Waller is currently being held in Escambia County Jail without bond, according to jail records.

NEW SMYRNA BEACH, Fla. - A 19-year-old Sanford man was bitten by a shark Sunday night off New Smyrna Beach, according to officials.

The incident happened around 7:45 p.m. near the Flagler Avenue beach approach.

According to beach officials, the man was wading in waist-deep water when he was bitten on the calf.

Title: Florida man and blind dog complete 1,100-mile hike
Summary:
MIAMI (AP) - A Florida man and his blind dog have completed a 1,100 mile hike across the Sunshine State.

Kyle Rohrig is an avid hiker and his Shiba Inu named Katana usually accompanies him. She's easily logged 30 miles a day on their past trails, but when Japanese hunting dog lost both eyes to Glaucoma two months before the trek, he worried how she would fare on the trail.

Along with a friend, they headed north on the trail from Big Cypress near Miami in January and finished April 1 at Fort Pickens near Pensacola.

The Daytona Beach News-Journal reports Rohrig hoisted the 21-pound Katana onto his backpack when they approached deep swampy areas and treacherous spots. He estimates he carried her for more than 800 miles.

Title: See Bryan Adams, plan for Rob Thomas, Brian Regan in Florida
Summary:
Each week, the USA Today Network Florida will provide you details on some of the hottest acts in the state.

The Hot Ticket offers the latest on upcoming concerts, shows or ticket sale information from South Florida to Pensacola and places in-between.

We want to inform you about a favorite musician, comedian, play or other entertainer scheduled to perform next week with information such as when tickets go on sale for a show and where to find tickets already available.

If you want to find out about a show not listed or when tickets go on sale for performance, email dave.osborn@naplesnews.com or reach out to him on Twitter @Ndn_dosborn.

Bryan Adams

Bryan Adams will perform in Florida and near Pensacola in May 2019. (Photo: Owen Sweeney / Invision / AP)

There's no question Michael Jackson was the king of pop in the 1980s, and Madonna wasn't far behind. But if there's a Mount Rushmore of rockers from that era, Bryan Adams certainly deserves consideration.

The Canadian songwriter and musician ‚Äî with his first major hit "Cuts Like A Knife" ‚Äî performs May 6 in Jacksonville, May 7 in St. Petersburg and May 10 at the Wharf Amphitheater in Orange Beach, Alabama, near Pensacola with tickets for as little as about $20.

Adams charted other mega-hits, including "Summer of '69," "This Time" from his debut 1983 album, "Cuts Like A Knife" and "Run To You" from the 1984 album "Reckless."

Plan ahead

Rob Thomas' tour swings into Florida in July 2019, with concerts scheduled in Boca Raton, St. Petersburg, Orlando and Jacksonville. (Photo: Photo courtesy Rob Thomas)

Rob Thomas

Rob Thomas is known as the front-man for Matchbox 20, but perhaps his greatest claim to fame was singing on Santana's wildly successful song "Smooth" that he co-wrote.

It won three Grammys in 2000, including Song of the Year and as last year Billboard considered the second most successful song of all time after Chubby Checker's 1960 hit "The Twist."

Thomas and his "Chip Tooth Tour" into the Sunshine State this summer, with concerts set for July 2 at Mizner Park in Boca Raton; July 3 at Hard Rock Live Orlando; July 5 at the Mahaffey Theater in St. Petersburg; and July 6 at Daily's Place in Jacksonville.

His Matchbox 20 hits have remained pop music staples in recent years, including "Real World,""3AM" and "Push."

Brian Regan (Photo: Brian Friedman)

Brian Regan

Jerry Seinfeld has called him one of his favorite comedians, and Brian Regan has earned his stature among standup legends.

The South Florida native tours it seems constantly, and returns to Florida with shows July 26 at Barbara B. Mann Hall in Fort Myers with tickets around $50 each.

The next night, Regan is at the Mahaffey Theater in St. Petersburg and tickets start around $40.

Regan is known for his clean comedy, with popular skits including "Say Eight" and "Doughnut Lady."

He still prides himself on being able to walk in public pretty much anonymously; a few years ago in an interview with the Naples Daily News, Regan discussed how he and his children had just spent a day at Disney World in Orlando and he went unrecognized.

Please try again soon, or contact Customer Service at 1-844-900-7105. Delivery: Thurs Invalid email address Thank you! You're almost signed up for SWFL Eats Keep an eye out for an email to confirm your newsletter registration. More newsletters

"I've never been the golden boy," he explained. "I don't have a huge following. I have a big following. I'm not complaining.

"Every once in a while somebody knows who I am, which is cool. But it's certainly not an issue I have to worry about."

Summary:
Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. WFLA photo

PINELLAS COUNTY, Fla. (WFLA) - A homeowner opened fire on a suspected intruder late Tuesday night, according to the St. Petersburg Police Department.

At about 1140 p.m., officers responded to reports of shots fired at a home in the area of 27th Avenue N. and 28th Street.

Police said a man was shot when he allegedly tried to break into the residence.

The extent of his injuries is unknown, but police said he was rushed to the hospital in stable condition.

There is no threat to the public.

Further information was not immediately available.

Title: CSX surprises children of military families with new bikes
Summary:
JACKSONVILLE, Fla. - Some of the youngest members of the military community got a surprise Tuesday they won't soon forget.

In support of military families, CSX and Blue Star families surprised kids with new bicycles.

Emily Leeds is the wife of a Navy man and a mother of three children. She was keeping the surprise a secret for days.

"They have been haggling all day to know what the surprise was," Leeds said. "It's a great thing for them to have as an activity to do for the summer."

It was totally worth it given the reaction she got from her children. They plan on doing a lot of riding over the summer.

Bryan Tucker, CSX's communication director, has a special love for military families.

"Not only does it make me think about when I got my first bike, but being a military brat myself, I understand the sacrifices and the challenges that some of these families go through every day," Tucker said. "It's extra special for me."

There are more than 43 million members of the military community in the United States. According to Blue Star Families' survey, 48% of military families do not feel like they're part of the civilian communities. Tuesday's surprise makes the connection stronger.

The partnership to surprise the families was launched at CSX's Jacksonville office. It plans on expanding the program to other offices around the country.

Copyright 2019 by WJXT News4Jax - All rights reserved.
Address: 4 Broadcast Pl, Jacksonville, FL 32207, USA

Title: FHP: Video shows man who tries to ram, shoot law enforcement
Summary:
FHP: Video shows man who tries to ram, shoot law enforcement

Deputies were almost run over and a trooper was nearly shot during a police pursuit Sunday, according to Florida Highway Patrol troopers. The pursuit spanned Citrus and Sumter counties. Dashcam video released Monday shows much of the pursuit, including a Pursuit Intervention Technique, or PIT manuever, which ended the chase. Deputies first went after the suspect because they say the pickup he was driving was stolen. Investigators say he tried to run over two deputies on Highway 41. Once troopers joined the pursuit on County Road 476, they say he took out a gun and fired off three shots toward them. One of the bullets hit a trooper's windshield.Travis Lovett, 22, from Bushnell is the suspect and was hospitalized after the crash. He also faces very serious charges, including fleeing and eluding law enforcement and stealing a vehicle and other charges. No one else was hurt in the pursuit.

Title: Deltona man has car stolen with his dog inside
Summary:
VOLUSIA COUNTY, Fla. - A Deltona man hopes to be reunited with his dog after his car was stolen Sunday.

The Volusia County Sheriff's Office said the victim was returning a shopping cart at the Publix on Saxon Boulevard when he saw his blue 2017 Kia Forte being driven away from the area.

Investigators said his 15-year-old Chihuahua was in the car.

The theft happened around noon.

The victim loaded up his car with the groceries he bought and went to return the cart.

After leaving the keys in the ignition with the car running, the victim watched his car leave the parking lot.

The license plate is DMWN47.

The car was last seen on Fairhaven Street.

Anyone with information about the dog or the car is asked to call 386-248-1777.

Title: Father of Pensacola man killed in crash on Easter dies in hospital
Summary:
The father of a Pensacola man who was killed in a three-vehicle crash on Easter has also died due to his injuries.

Randy Riley, 49, was pronounced dead Monday at Baptist Hospital, according to Florida Highway Patrol.

The family told the News Journal last week that the father was in critical condition at the hospital following the wreck, which claimed the life of 22-year-old Nelson Riley.

Authorities say 47-year-old Marie Ann Simpkins was driving erratically in the moments before she allegedly ran a red light at Fairfield Drive and North W Street and rammed her vehicle into the car driven by Randy Riley.

His son, Nelson Riley, was a passenger inside the car and was pronounced dead at the scene.

Marie Ann Simpkins (Photo: Escambia County Jail)

'He will be missed': Pensacola man killed in crash was aspiring rapper, loving dad

Marie Anne Simpkins arrest report: Witnesses describe erratic driving by Pensacola woman accused of causing deadly crash

The driver of the third vehicle involved in the crash was transported to the hospital with minor injuries.

Hours after the wreck, investigators said Simpkins was showing "signs of impairment as a result of drugs," according to her arrest report.

Authorities also allegedly found marijuana in her possession while she was being booked into jail.

She ‚Äã‚Äãhas been charged with vehicular homicide; driving under the influence ‚Äì manslaughter; driving under the influence ‚Äì serious bodily injury; and reckless driving causing serious bodily injuries, according to the State Attorney's Office.

Two passengers inside Simpkins' car at the time of the crash, a 19-year-old and a 4-year-old, were both transported to the hospital, where they were treated and released.

Nelson Riley (Photo: Courtesy of Jamina Riley.)

Title: Man dies in crash with semitruck on US 192, troopers say
Summary:
OSCEOLA COUNTY, Fla. - A 72-year-old man was killed Monday morninh when a semitruck crashed into the back of his car on U.S. 192 in Osceola County, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.

The crash happened at 4:45 a.m. near Crabgrass Road.

Troopers said the semitruck was traveling eastbound on U.S. 192 in the right through lane and for an unknown reason, a Kia Optima was stopped in the same lane.

The semitruck driver was unable to stop in time to avoid hitting the back of the Kia Optima, according to the report.

Troopers said the Daytona Beach man in the Kia was not wearing a seat belt. He died at the scene of the crash.

The incident remains under investigation.

Title: Man, blind dog complete 1,100-mile hike across Florida
Summary:
MIAMI - A Florida man and his blind dog have completed an 1,100-mile hike across the Sunshine State.

Kyle Rohrig is an avid hiker and his Shiba Inu named Katana usually accompanies him. She's easily logged 30 miles a day on their past trails, but when the Japanese hunting dog lost both eyes to glaucoma two months before the trek, he worried how she would fare on the trail.

Along with a friend, they headed north on the trail from Big Cypress near Miami in January and finished April 1 at Fort Pickens near Pensacola.

The Daytona Beach News-Journal reports Rohrig hoisted the 21-pound Katana onto his backpack when they approached deep swampy areas and treacherous spots. He estimates he carried her for more than 800 miles.

CLAIRE: ASHLIE HICKS TOOK A DIFFERENT ROUTE TO WORK TUESDAY; A PROBLEM WITH HER USUAL PATH PUT HER IN THE VICINITY OF EAST LAMBERT AND NORTH ANDERSON JUST AS THIS HOME AT THE INTERSECTION WAS BURNING. CLAIRE: SHERIFF‚ÄôS OFFICE CIVILIAN CLERK ASHLIE HICKS SAYS THE FRONT PORCH OF THE HOME WAS ON FIRE AND A NEIGHBOR TOLD HER SOMEONE WAS IN THE ROOM JU BEYOND, SLEEPING ON A COUCH. THE NEIGHBOR, WITH NO CELL PHONE AND TWO SMALL CHILDREN, COULDN‚ÄôT HELP, SO IT WAS HICKS WHO CALLED 911 AND WHILE ON THE PHONE, RAISED FOR THE BACK DOOR. HICKS SAYS A MAN, WOMAN AND THE WOMAN‚ÄôS MOTHER WERE SOUND ASLEEP WITH NO IDEA THEIR HOME WAS FAST BECOMING AN INFERNO. >> EVEN WHEN I DID GET THEM AWAKE, THEY WERE STILL OUT OF IT . WAKING UP OUT OF A DEEP SLEEP WITH SOME STRANGER SCREAMING THAT THEIR HOUSE IS ON FIRE CLAIRE: THOUGH THE HOUSE IS A TOTAL LOSS HICKS GOT THE FAMILY OUT, HELPED GET THEIR ANIMALS TO SAFETY, TOO. SHE RESISTS ANY TALK OF HEROISM. >> I HOPE ANYONE ELSE WOULD DO THE SAME. CLAIRE: THIS BUSINESS CENTER ON EAST MOODY BOULEVARD IS HA

Advertisement Flagler County Sheriff's Office employee credited with saving family from burning home Share Shares Copy Link Copy

A Flager County Sheriff's Office employee is being credited with saving residents after their home caught fire.Ashlie Hicks usual path to work on Tuesday had a few problems, forcing her to take a different route.The path took Hicks to the vicinity of East Lambert and North AndersonStreet while a home at the intersection was on fire."I just was banging on the door yelling and screaming," Hicks told WESH 2 News.Ashlie Hicks, a civilian clerk, said the front porch of the home was on fire and a neighbor told her someone was in the room just beyond, sleeping on a couch.The neighbor, with no cell phone and two small children, couldn't help, so Hicks jumped in.While on the phone with 911, Hicks raced for the back door. She said a man, woman and the woman's mother were sound asleep with no idea their home was on fire. "Even when I did get them awake, they were still out of it, you know? Waking up out of a deep sleep with some stranger screaming that their house is on fire," Hicks said.Though the house is a total loss, Hicks was able to get the family out, and helped get their animals to safety too.She said she marvels that a roadblock on the way to work put her at the scene. "Different change of events in the morning led me to their house," Hicks said.Hicks said she resists any talk of heroism. "I just knew there were people inside and their house was on fire and they needed help," Hicks said. "I would hope that anybody would do the same."A business center on East Moody Boulevard is having its grand opening Saturday. The business is almost directly in front of the home that burned so they've decided to make the grand opening a benefit for the fire victims.

Title: New lacrosse club announced to serve South Walton, surrounding areas
Summary:
Dedicated to spreading the game of lacrosse in South Walton and its surrounding areas, the Panhandle Lacrosse Club announced its establishment and now invites those interested in playing the fastest game on two feet to an orientation meeting at 5:30 p.m. Tuesday, May 7, in Room 119 of the Northwest Florida State College South Walton Center.

‚ÄúWhile we hope to expand to more teams in future years, for this first year, we‚Äôre offering high-school aged men the opportunity to play,‚Äù said Coach Joshua Schmidt. ‚ÄúWe will mainly be focused on giving players of all skill levels the chance to strengthen their abilities.‚Äù

Schmidt, a former college lacrosse player, said he approaches the game with a player-forward philosophy and is committed to ensuring each athlete improves their lacrosse knowledge throughout their time with the Panhandle Lacrosse Club. With this approach, the Club hopes to build on each player's confidence, teamwork and sportsmanship, ensuring the game's integrity and growth across the Florida Panhandle.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what these summer leagues are supposed to be about,‚Äù said Schmidt. ‚ÄúLearning new skills, keeping players sharp and just enjoying the game.‚Äù

Practices are held on Sundays from 3-5 p.m. and Thursdays from 2:30-4:30 p.m. at the South Walton Boys & Girls Club. The $150 registration fee includes eight to 10 practice sessions, one pair of shorts, one reversible pinnie and one shooter shirt. For an additional $50, players can compete in the Fourth Annual Tampa Summer Jam lacrosse tournament. Still, players are required to provide their own equipment and travel/lodging.

‚ÄúWe want to give every young man that steps through our organization the opportunity to play lacrosse at the highest level,‚Äù said Schmidt. ‚ÄúAnd this program is going to help them do that.‚Äù

For more information about the team, sponsorship opportunities or to register, visit www.panhandlelax.com or contact Schmidt at panhandlelaxclub@gmail.com.
Address: 2 Eglin Pkwy NE, Fort Walton Beach, FL 32548, USA

Title: Denver 'space tug' startup Atomos wins $100K Rise of the Rest pitch contest at Groundswell
Summary:
CLOSE Led by AOL co-founder Steve Case, Rise of the Rest toured the Space Coast and hosts $100,000 startup pitch contest at Groundswell Startups in Melbourne. Tim Shortt, FLORIDA TODAY

Denver startup Atomos Nuclear and Space ‚Äî which is developing electric-propulsion "space tugs" to move satellites into varying orbits ‚Äî flew cross-country to Melbourne and claimed Tuesday's $100,000 Rise of the Rest pitch competition.

But look for Atomos to return ‚Äî to try to establish a presence on Cape Canaveral.

"I love the Space Coast. Originally Australian, I feel very landlocked in Colorado. I‚Äôve worked at Kennedy Space Center on a couple of programs. And we‚Äôll be back there in the future," Atomos Chief Executive Officer Vanessa Clark said, minutes after accepting the ceremonial check from AOL co-founder Steve Case.

"Besides launch, we don‚Äôt have integration facilities. We don‚Äôt have access to the resources that there are in Florida," Clark said.

"So we definitely want to come back. We definitely want to talk about how to partner," she said.

Buy Photo Atomos Nuclear and Space Chief Executive Officer Vanessa Clark won the Rise of the Rest $100,000 pitch competition Tuesday at Groundswell Startups in Melbourne. (Photo: TIM SHORTT/ FLORIDA TODAY)

Tuesday's Space Coast event was the 40th city visited by Rise of the Rest, which showcases startup ecosystems across America that are far removed from Silicon Valley, Austin, Boston and other established hubs.

A $150 million seed fund launched in December by Revolution, a Washington, D.C. venture capital firm, finances the campaign ‚Äî which was featured by "60 Minutes" last month. The firm is headed by Case and "Hillbilly Elegy" author J.D. Vance.

Clark's successful pitch topped seven rival companies, including three from the Space Coast:

‚Ä¢ BoMax Hydrogen (Space Coast), which is developing a carbon-free, light-driven method to produce hydrogen to generate electricity.

‚Ä¢ Helicon Chemical Co. (Space Coast), which develops next-generation rocket fuel for the military and commercial space industries.

‚Ä¢ Hermeus (Atlanta, Georgia), which engineers and manufactures Mach 5 aircraft.

‚Ä¢ Hydrosat (Washington, D.C.), which specializes in satellite imagery data for the agriculture industry.

‚Ä¢ Indemnis (Anchorage, Alaska), which develops and manufactures parachute recovery systems for drones.

‚Ä¢ Reaction Dynamics (Montreal, Quebec), which develops space transportation systems for launch providers.

‚Ä¢ Tomahawk Robotics (Space Coast), which provides control software for robots.

Buy Photo AOL co-founder Steve Case delivers a Rise of the Rest fireside cat with (left) J.D. Vance, managing partner, and moderator Kim Hart, managing editor of Axios, at Groundswell Startups in Melbourne. (Photo: TIM SHORTT/ FLORIDA TODAY)

Groundswell Startups: AOL co-founder Steve Case to host $100,000 tech startup pitch contest in Melbourne

Groundswell Startups: No more 'prick and stick:' Alertgy working on noninvasive glucometer for diabetes patients

The event drew an estimated crowd of 350 to Groundswell Startups, the Melbourne tech incubator on U.S. 1.

Rise of the Rest is in the midst of a Florida road trip featuring $100,000 pitch contests that kicked off Monday in Orlando. The organization's signature red bus will visit Tampa on Wednesday, Miami on Thursday, and San Juan, Puerto Rico, on Friday.

While judging Tuesday's pitch contest, Case said Vance told him the Space Coast field "may have been the best set of entrepreneurs, the best pitches he's ever seen."

AOL co-founder Steve Case steps off his Rise of the Rest tour bus Tuesday at the Florida Institute of Technology (Photo: Florida Institute of Technology)

Earlier Tuesday, Rise of the Rest toured the Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex, Blue Origin, OneWeb Satellites, Rocket Crafters, Embraer and the Florida Institute of Technology's Digital Scholarship Laboratory.

"This is a region that has done some of the most innovative things ever. Putting a man on the moon was crazy to even try," Case told the Groundswell crowd during a fireside chat.

The billionaire likened the $100,000 venture capital investment with a "booster rocket" that can accelerate a startup's development.

"We have no idea which cities will rise the fastest. We don't know if it's Melbourne. We don't know if it's Des Moines. We don't know if it's Minneapolis. We really don't know. And the reason we don't know has nothing do to what we do ‚Äî and everything to do what you do," Case said, challenging the crowd.

"Grab this opportunity and seize it as a moment to say, 'Let's figure out a way to become even more of a startup city. Be more focused on innovation. Welcome the risk-taking,'" Case said.

"Because this is a region that clearly, based on its storied history, has the potential for an extremely bright future," he said.

Buy Photo The crowd claps during Tuesday's Rise of the Rest $100,000 pitch competition at Groundswell Startups in Melbourne. (Photo: TIM SHORTT/ FLORIDA TODAY)

During her pitch, Clark said Atomos is developing space tugs ‚Äî or electric-propulsion powered spacecraft designed to move satellites ‚Äî that may someday serve as "connecting flights" in Earth's orbit. She said Atomos could position satellites from telecommunications companies and other customers 30 percent cheaper and 50 percent faster than traditional rockets.

"Rockets no longer need to go all the way to a specific orbit for a specific satellite. With space tugs, they can transport all satellites to a dropping point. And we'll take them from there," Clark said.

Atomos hopes to launch its first vehicle into space in 2021.

Axios Managing Editor Kim Hart moderated the 45-minute fireside chat with Case and Vance, who criticized the Silicon Valley mindset.

"Wouldn't you rather be focused on well, quite literally, the stars ‚Äî and not on the next dog walking app? I mean, that seems to be like a pretty easy and straightforward proposition," Vance said.

Neale is the South Brevard watchdog reporter at FLORIDA TODAY.

Contact Neale at 321-242-3638 or rneale@floridatoday.com.

Twitter: @RickNeale1

Support local journalism: Subscribe to FLORIDA TODAY at floridatoday.com/subscribe.

Title: Man accused of killing 5 in newspaper massacre takes up an insanity defense
Summary:
Hide Transcript Show Transcript

NEWS AT AN. THE ATTORNEYS FOR THE MAN CHARGED IN THE CAPITAL GAZETTE SHOOTING SAY HE IS CLIENT -- CHANGING HIS PLEA TO AN INSANITY DEFENSE. STAN: HIS LAWYER HAD UNTIL THE CLOSE OF BUSINESS TO DECIDE IF THEY WANTED TO CHANGE IT. THEY SAID HE WILL PLEAD NOT GUILTY, CRIMINALLY REASONABLE -- RESPONSIBLE FOR BY REASON OF INSANITY

Advertisement Man accused of killing 5 in newspaper massacre takes up an insanity defense Share Shares Copy Link Copy

The man accused of killing five people at the Capital Gazette newspaper in Annapolis, Maryland, changed his plea Monday to not guilty by reason of insanity.Lawyers for Jarrod Ramos said in a court filing that the 39-year-old Ramos was not criminally responsible "because of a mental disorder." Monday's filing in the Anne Arundel County Circuit Court also said he lacked the "capacity to appreciate the criminality of his conduct."Five people were fatally shot in June 2018 in the Capital Gazette newsroom. Ramos was indicted on 23 charges in the attack, including first-degree murder. Ramos had initially pleaded not guilty, and the change of plea filed Monday maintains the not guilty plea.If Ramos were ultimately found not criminally responsible, he could be confined to a mental health prison facility. A November trial has been scheduled.Ramos has been charged with first-degree murder in the deaths of Gerald Fischman, Rob Hiaasen, John McNamara, Rebecca Ann Smith and Wendi Winters.At a court hearing earlier this month, an attorney for Ramos made several references to his client's "bizarre language" and "bizarre behavior" leading up to the June 28 mass shooting. Attorney William Davis said Ramos had "longstanding" mental health issues and a period of "mental health disturbances." Davis also said a mental health expert has been working with the defense.The state will conduct its own evaluation to determine whether Ramos was not criminally responsible. A doctor independent from the prosecution will write a report with recommendations and that report will then be sent to defense attorneys, prosecutors and the court.Generally, a judge or jury would consider whether the defendant is not criminally responsible after the trial.Prosecutors are seeking life in prison without possibility of parole.Police said Ramos had used a shotgun to blast his way inside the newsroom. He also has been charged with attempted murder, assault and gun crimes.According to prosecutors, Ramos carefully planned the attack and barricaded the rear exit of the office to prevent people from escaping. Police say they captured Ramos hiding under a desk at the Capital Gazette office after the attack.Ramos, of Laurel, Maryland, had a well-documented history of harassing the newspaper's journalists. He filed a lawsuit against the paper in 2012, alleging he was defamed in an article about his conviction in a criminal harassment case in 2011. The Capital had published a story describing allegations by a woman who said Ramos harassed her online for months. The defamation suit was dismissed as groundless, and Ramos railed against staff at the newspaper in profanity-laced tweets.In the days following the attack, area judges and an attorney received letters that threatened the newsroom and were signed with Ramos' name.
Address: Northcorp Business Park, Palm Beach Gardens, FL 33410, USA

Title: North Fort Myers man convicted as career criminal, seven charges in less than a year
Summary:
CLOSE This is a six-month review of the most-read crime stories in Lee County on news-press.com from September 2018 to February 2019. Vonna Keomanyvong, vonna.keomanyvong@naplesnews.com; 239-213-5380

Harrison Rivera III, of North Fort Myers, was sentenced on multiple cases as a career criminal and habitual felony offender on drug and gun charges and a case involving a battery.

He will serve a minimum of 36 months, according to State Attorney's Office documents released Monday. Two of the charges carried a sentence of up to six years.

In the first case, from March 2018, deputies found Rivera hiding in a North Fort Myers bedroom as Lee County Sheriff's deputies served a warrant on another person, the documents showed. As a sergeant went into the room, he saw three firearms and drugs in a closet.

Harrison Rivera III (Photo: Lee County Sheriff's Office)

More: Bomb squad searches home of Cape man accused of threatening Lee judges on social media

As he retrieved the weapons, Rivera became argumentative, then fled, a report indicated. Deputies caught him and placed him in handcuffs. When they took him outside, he jumped off a 4-foot stoop and ran. They quickly caught him again.

As they searched him, they found a key in his waistband, which opened a lock on the closet containing the drugs and weapons, the release stated.

He was charged and released on bond, but failed to appear in court, a release stated.

Not long after, Cape Coral Police made contact with a vehicle that appeared to be broken down in a parking lot, the release stated. The driver was making motions near the door, and as the officer walked up to the car he saw a firearm. The officer called for back up and asked the male driver in the passenger seat to exit the vehicle. It was Rivera.

Officers searched the car and found drug paraphernalia, the report indicates.

While incarcerated, Rivera attacked an inmate at the Lee County jail.

Assistant State Attorney Christine Cummins handled the case.

Title: Bomb squad searches home of Cape man who allegedly threated Lee judges on social media
Summary:
A man at a Cape Coral home along NW 15th Terrace prompted the closure of the street and evacuation of other residents after he went on social media and threatened Lee County judges.

The Lee County Sheriff‚Äôs Office shut down 15th Terrace after the man, whom the Sheriff's Office declined to identify, mde the threats Monday night.

"Yesterday evening, early evening, the Lee County Sheriff's Office received a complaint and a report of an adult male who was utilizing social media to make threats against judges in our county," Sheriff Carmine Marceno said at the scene Tuesday morning.

Marceno said deputies and detectives went to the home. The man at the home armed himself and tried to flee with deputies giving chase. The man was taken into custody and arrested, the sheriff said, and an active investigation was started.

The sheriff also said that investigation by his office and the Cape Coral Police Department found suspicious items in the home.

A bomb squad unit was seen investigating the home at 1113 NW 15th Terrace.

Buy Photo Members of the LCSO bomb squad inspect the area surrounding a house in a Cape Coral neighborhood after reports of a bomb threat Tuesday, April 30, 2019. (Photo: Ricardo Rolon/The News-Press)

Two LCSO deputies in bomb gear approached the front of the house, placed a black container in the driveway and then walked around the back of the home.

Deputies told residents along NW 15th Terrace near the intersection of NW 11th Court in Cape Coral to leave their homes while the investigation was underway.

‚ÄúWe were told to evacuate by officers,‚Äù JoAnne Mugica said from her SUV as she drove away from her home and under police tape. ‚ÄúWe were surprised for sure. Cape Coral is always so quiet.‚Äù

Mugica said she didn‚Äôt know the person who lives at the home involved in the investigation, but said that her husband had spoken with the man on occasion.

‚ÄúHe told my husband he got married to Beyonc√©,‚Äù she said.

Another resident, Leonard VanBuskirk, said he hadn't heard anything until he walked out of his home earlier to walk his dogs.

"I saw all the (cruisers) parked there," he said, adding he really didn't know the resident at the home in question very well.

"He has a zillion pots that he grows herbs in," he said.

Northwest 15th Terrace was blocked off between NW 10th Place and NW 12th Place and a bomb squad vehicle was parked nearby.

Title: Dashcam video captures patrol truck slamming into woman's convertible
Summary:
A 62-year-old Fernandina Beach woman is lucky to be alive after a Nassau County Sheriff's Office truck slammed into her convertible Monday afternoon during a chase.

Deborah Westhouse was pulled over on the side of Fletcher Avenue South, near Matanzas Avenue, to get out of the way of the patrol truck heading northbound with its lights and siren on.

The deputy tried to turn left in front of her but instead slammed into the side of her car.

Dashcam video from the Nassau County Sheriff's Office shows the deputy originally driving at what appears to be normal speed with no lights or siren. He then makes a U-turn and heads south on Fletcher Avenue. Seconds later, he speeds up and that's when his lights and siren come on.

About a minute later, he makes another U-turn and heads back northbound.

The engine revving can be heard in the video as the deputy swerves through traffic. Drivers of other vehicles appear to do their best to pull over. Bicyclists can even be seen on the side of the road just feet away from the speeding patrol truck.

About two minutes into the video, Westhouse's white convertible can be seen. She is waving her hands in the air and appears to be waving deputies toward something, possibly a man who they were after.

Then, the deputy crashes into her convertible. She suffered minor injuries, but Joby Brewer, who was about to start his shift at the nearby A1A Express Discount, said it could have been a lot worse.

"It could have been if the sheriff's (deputy) had kept on going. If he had kept going, he could have totally ran directly head-on into that lady," Brewer said.

A Florida Highway Patrol report said the chase started at Peter's Point Beach, about a mile and a half south, when a deputy tried to make a traffic stop on a Hyundai in the parking lot and the driver drove off.

The deputy who initiated the original traffic stop was lucky to not suffer any injuries, as the driver who fled dragged him a short distance in the parking lot, troopers said.

Brewer said that Hyundai came flying into the store's parking lot, screeching its tires, and off to the north side of the building.

He said the man left the car and came inside the store.

"We had a couple squad cars and they pulled over the guy's boss because the kid had called his boss to pick him up and he was coming back here to the scene of the accident, came in the store to buy a pack of cigarettes and got caught," Brewer said.

Brewer said deputies were just seconds behind the man and that he watched him being arrested in the store's parking lot.

The man who was arrested was identified as William Ross III, according to a Nassau County Sheriff's Office report.

Ross, 27, was booked into the Nassau County jail on a variety of charges, including aggravated assault with a dangerous weapon, eluding police and possession of drug paraphernalia. His bond was set at $87,000, according to online jail records.

Westhouse's husband told News4Jax by the phone she is expected to be OK, but is understandably shaken up following the incident.
Address: 4 Broadcast Pl, Jacksonville, FL 32207, USA

Title: Daytona Beach Shores police attempt to identify sexual battery suspect
Summary:
DAYTONA BEACH SHORES, Fla. - Police in Daytona Beach Shores said they are attempting to identify a man wanted in connection with a sexual battery that happened last year.

On Monday, officers released surveillance photos of a man dressed in all black, who is about 30 years old with tan skin and a tattoo of a baby on his chest.

The sexual battery happened between May 17 and May 18, 2018, according to a news release. The victim said she met the unidentified man and she sexually battered him in a hotel room in the 3000 block of South Atlantic Avenue, authorities said.

The victim was a woman on vacation.

It's possible that the man was in town doing construction work and may have been staying with his boss or a group of construction workers at an unknown hotel in the area, according to police.

Anyone who lived, worked or spent time in the south side of Daytona Beach Shores during May and June of 2018 is asked to take a close look at the surveillance images.

If you recognize the man in the photos, call Detective Wilmot at 386-763-5335 or email mwilmot@cityofdbs.org. To remain anonymous, call Crime Stoppers at 1-888-277-TIPS (8477) and reference case number 180700098.

Address: 4466 N John Young Pkwy, Orlando, FL 32804, USA

Title: 100-year-old man killed in unusual crash involving sandhill cranes was World War II veteran
Summary:
CLOSE The Sandhill Crane is protected by the U.S. Migratory Bird Treaty Act and is a state-designated threatened species. Ginny Beagan, TCPALM

Robert "Tony" Schantz was surrounded by over 100 family and friends in November, beaming at the celebration centered around his 100th birthday. It was a good time for the widower and father of three, who was a World War II veteran.

The retired machinist moved to Florida with his wife three decades ago and spent his recent time carving animals and solving crossword puzzles.

‚ÄúHe lived a good life and served the Lord,‚Äù said Gay Harris, who lives in Springfield, Ohio, where her father was born.

Schantz died Sunday in what authorities said was an unusual traffic crash.

Schantz ‚Äî returning home from church ‚Äî was a passenger in a van driven by a granddaughter. The van swerved suddenly and struck two other cars to avoid a family of sandhill cranes walking across Wickham Road near Murrell Road.

The three-vehicle crash that followed happened about 10:30 a.m. Five people were taken to area hospitals.

RIP: 100-year-old man dies following Melbourne crash involving sandhill cranes

Archive story: A guy learns a little ‚Äî OK, a lot ‚Äî over 102 years

Schantz, who was able to talk with Florida Highway Patrol investigators at Holmes Regional Medical Center, was pronounced dead a short time later as doctors attempted to treat his severely injured leg. A law enforcement officer had applied a tourniquet to Schantz's leg at the scene.

"The crash is still under investigation," Kim Montes, spokeswoman for the Florida Highway Patrol, said Monday. "What you have to consider as a driver is that if you come upon a situation where other people have stopped in the roadway, you have to use due care," Montes said.

Police said Schantz was a passenger in a specially equipped 2016 Chrysler van driven by his 39-year-old granddaughter Suzanne Clark, who is a paraplegic. The pair were traveling westbound on Wickham Road when she spotted a 2010 BMW and a 1996 Toyota Avalon. Both the BMW and the Avalon were stopped in the westbound lane as a family of sandhill cranes began crossing the busy roadway, Montes said.

Clark suddenly moved to the right to avoid the BMW but then spotted the cranes in the roadway and veered back into the left lane, striking the rear of the BMW. The BMW lurched forward into the back of the Toyota Avalon.

Florida Highway Patrol investigators are reviewing a crash that happened at N. Wickham Road near intersection of Murrell Road Sunday. A 100-year-old passenger in one of the vehicles later died, authorities reported. (Photo: TIM SHORTT)

The birds ‚Äî a state-designated threatened species that are protected by the U.S. Migratory Bird Treaty Act ‚Äî frequently are seen nesting or walking about parts of Brevard County.

Over the years, there have been crashes involving animals, including at least one 2016 deadly crash in Indian Harbour Beach involving a bicycle striking a turtle, records show. Montes, however, said it was the first time she could recall a fatal crash involving sandhill cranes crossing the road.

Schantz, who lived in an Osprey mobile home, was in Brevard under the care of his daughter, Harris said. Schantz, an avid sportsman and bike rider, broke his hip during a bike ride last year.

"He would ride his bike 7 miles a day and rode it to a Walmart where he fell and broke his hip," she said of Schantz, who played semi-pro baseball in the years leading up to World War II. He also was an avid golfer.

According to Harris, years ago the centenarian participated in Space Coast Honor Flight ‚Äî a program that flies World War II, Korean War, and Vietnam veterans to visit their War Memorials in Washington D.C.

Archive story: At 103, he's figured out what matters -- but what, he asks, is 'streaming'?

Harris pointed out that her father came from a family known for longevity, including an uncle she says lived until 114.

"Personally, it was just a tragic accident. He could have lived longer but the Lord knows. And we don't blame anyone at all," Harris said.

Schantz is survived by his three daughters.

She said her father might have seen the odd nature of the accident with a bit of humor.

"He carved dogs and howling wolves. He was a very talented guy. But looking back, he would have thought it was so odd, and would have thought it was funny eventually, that maybe this is the way the Lord wanted him to go," Harris said.

Contact Gallop at 321-242-3642 or jdgallop@floridatoday.com. Twitter: @JDGallop

Title: Deputies: Florida woman slapped man, stabbed mattress to try and sober him up
Summary:
Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed.

NEW PORT RICHEY, Fla. (WFLA) - A Pasco County woman is facing charges after deputies say she assaulted a man in an attempt to sober him up.

Pasco deputies were called a home on Hummingbird Lane in New Port Richey just before 1 a.m. Sunday and arrested 39-year-old Amber Lynnee Grace.

According to an arrest report, Grace slapped the victim in the face during an argument inside the home. The victim told deputies he then walked away from Grace and went to his bedroom.

Deputies say the victim later woke up and found Grace standing over him with a kitchen knife raised above her head. Grace then stabbed the bed with the knife, the arrest report says.

The victim told deputies he was scared he was going to be stabbed by Grace. A responding deputy noted in the arrest report that there was a slice in the bedsheets just inches away from the pillow where the victim's head was.

The arrest report says Grace admitted to slapping the man in the face and said she did it because he was drunk and thought it would help his intoxication level. Deputies say she also admitted to stabbing the bed to "shock" the victim.

Grace was arrested and charged with domestic aggravated assault and domestic battery.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: Palm Bay man threw cinder block out of moving vehicle as 'prank,' police say
Summary:
PALM BAY, Fla. - Upon finding a cinder block, a 20-year-old Palm Bay man thought it would be a good idea to throw it out of a moving car at another vehicle as a "prank," police said.

Kadeem Tomlinson (Photo: Brevard County Sheriff's Office)

A man told police he was driving on Garvey Road Friday when part of a cinder block was tossed out of the driver's side of a Mitsubishi four-door. The partial cement block hit the hood of his SUV, bouncing up and nearly hitting the windshield, according to the Palm Bay police report.

The victim's young daughter was sitting in the front passenger's seat and could have been seriously injured if the cinder block had broken the windshield, according to the report.

Police said the victim followed the vehicle the cinder block came from, but the black car swerved in and out of different neighborhoods to try to lose him. After the car went onto Malabar Road, almost colliding with a motorcycle, police pulled over the car, according to the report.

The victim said he followed the traffic stop and waited to speak with officers. The motorcycle rider also stopped because they were almost hit by the same vehicle, according to the report.

Police said the spoke with the driver vehicle who denied knowing where the cinder block came from or how the victim's SUV was damaged. The rear driver's side passenger Kadeem Tomlinson, 20, Palm Bay, also denied any involvement.

However, the other two passengers in the suspect's car told police Tomlinson picked up a cinder block before getting into the car and said he was going to throw it at a random car as a "prank." Both passengers said Tomlinson threw the cinder block out of the driver's side back window and they all heard a loud bang.

Tomlinson is charged with throwing a deadly missile and criminal mischief.

Copyright 2019 by WKMG ClickOrlando - All rights reserved.

Title: 'Hero' shot and killed trying to stop robbery at adult arcade in Jacksonville
Summary:
0 'Hero' shot and killed trying to stop robbery at adult arcade in Jacksonville

Police are searching for the gunman they say killed a customer at the Dream Arcade in Biltmore Wednesday night.

MORE: Jacksonville police: Man shot, killed trying to intervene in robbery

Neighbors are calling the shooting victim a hero after investigators say he put himself in the line of fire to stop a robbery attempt.

TRENDING:

Police tell Action News Jax the gunman fired at least one shot, killing the customer inside the arcade.

Jasmine Allen lives near the business, and says she‚Äôs disturbed by news of a shooting like this so close to home.

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs sad,‚Äù she said. ‚Äú‚Ä¶he was just trying to be a good Samaritan. I guess, like a hero.‚Äù

Action News Jax uncovered at least 20 calls for service to the Dream Arcade from the start of 2018 through Wednesday, May 1, 2019.

Action News Jax Reporter Ryan Nelson sat down with District 2 Councilman Al Ferraro to discuss legislation he‚Äôs filed to address safety concerns at adult arcades.

Ferraro told us he was not surprised by Wednesday‚Äôs events at the Dream Arcade after several violent incidents at arcades around the city.

STAY UPDATED: Download the Action News Jax app for live updates on breaking stories

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve had prostitution, we‚Äôve had drugs, we‚Äôve had all kinds of things,‚Äù he said.

Ferraro‚Äôs proposing a bill to outlaw "simulated gambling devices" for commercial and promotional purposes.

First-time violators found guilty would be hit with a $2,000 fine, while second and third-time violators would face $5,000 and $10,000 penalties, respectively.

Violators wouldn‚Äôt be able to apply for a license until penalties were fully paid.

Ferraro says the bill is necessary to enhance safety in the arcades and the communities around them.

‚ÄúWe want to have some teeth into the regulations to have them enforced,‚Äù he said.

The bill aims to keep adult arcades from offering illegal gambling options to the public.

While adult arcades are regulated by state law, the bill‚Äôs text says there‚Äôs conflict with Florida statutes.

Nelson went to the arcade owner‚Äôs listed address to learn what they‚Äôre doing to keep customers safe. He left his contact information with a family member of the owner but did not hear back.

We requested an interview with Sheriff Mike Williams. We did not receive a response.
