Title: Mondesi, Royals jump on Rays early, hold on for 3-2 win
Summary:
- Adalberto Mondesi hit a two-run homer in a three-run first inning, and the Kansas City Royals held on to beat the Tampa Bay Rays 3-2 on Wednesday in the opener of a doubleheader.

Jakob Junis (3-2) won his second consecutive start, both against the Rays, after winning at Tampa Bay on April 24. He allowed two runs on six hits in 6 1/3 innings, walking two and striking out two.

Mondesi is batting .338 (24-for-71) with 12 extra-base hits at Kauffman Stadium, the most by any AL player in his home park. He is second in the AL in RBIs with 26.

The Royals jumped on Rays opener Ryne Stanek (0-1). Whit Merrifield led off with a double and stole third before Mondesi drilled his fourth homer this season to right field. Alex Gordon walked and later scored as the first four batters reached safely.

Tampa Bay began the day having allowed just four first-inning runs while scoring 29, both best in the majors. Stanek had made seven scoreless appearances as the opener this year, holding opponents to a .114 batting average (4-for-35). His lone inning Wednesday increased his ERA from 1.20 to 2.81.

Jalen Beeks took over in the second and limited the Royals to one hit over 6 2/3 innings, fanning six.

Ian Kennedy worked two scoreless innings for his second save in three chances.

The Royals benefited from an unusual baserunning gaffe in the fourth, when Avisa√≠l Garc√≠a was called out on appeal for failing to retouch second base. After Gordon caught Kevin Kiermaier's long drive to left, Garc√≠a appeared to touch second and make a slight turn toward third before running directly back to first.

Kansas City became the last AL team to reach double digits in wins.

ROSTER MOVES

The Rays added RHP Austin Pruitt from Triple-A Durham as their 26th man for Game 2 of the doubleheader, while the Royals recalled RHP Glenn Sparkman from Omaha to start the second game.

UP NEXT

Blake Snell (2-2, 2.54 ERA), last year's AL Cy Young winner, starts in the second game against Sparkman (0-1, 8.10), who is making his first start of the season.

The Associated Press contributed to this report.
Address: 35 Skyline Dr, Lake Mary, FL 32746, USA

Title: 'Transit' inspires sobering reflections on past, present and future | Film review
Summary:
Paula Beer and Franz Rogowski star in "Transit." (Photo: Music Box Films)

Mayhem, desperation and apathy reign in Christian Petzold‚Äôs ‚ÄúTransit,‚Äù an intense drama that depicts the horror and chaos of refugee life. In the film, based on Anna Seghers's 1942 novel of the same name, we follow Georg, a man attempting to leave Paris as a fascist German force invades the city.

Georg is tasked with delivering a letter to a celebrated author before he escapes ‚Äî a responsibility that sets off a chain of events he cannot stop. As Georg reels through the traumatic space of an invaded and oppressed city, he makes powerful, if brief, connections with other refugees, who face love, loss, despair and hopelessness.

‚ÄúTransit‚Äù demands us to consider important questions ‚Äî not only about humankind‚Äôs capacity for compassion and bravery, but also about our indifference and callousness. We are left reflecting on what our responsibility is to help other human beings in crisis, and whether the notion of historical progress is a myth we tell ourselves to ease our guilt.

As an audience, we are perplexed and disturbed by the disjointed chain of events. The film disrupts the idea that we have learned from past atrocities, and will not allow such disasters to repeat themselves.

Much of the film‚Äôs power lies in its ambiguity. Stable and linear concepts of time are blurred and little concrete information is offered. Whether we are we looking at scenes from the 1930s or present day remains entirely unclear. The fascist oppression we see reminds us of Nazi Germany, but distinctive symbols such as swastikas and SS gear are noticeably absent.

What is certain is that specific populations of people have been labeled as undesirables, that their country, their home, is no longer safe. The film‚Äôs close-up of Georg‚Äôs chaotic experience reminds us that much of the panic and atrocity of war takes place in the background.

Although murder and torture are not at the forefront of the film, we are painfully aware, as Georg is, of the horrific fates await those who are captured. We are refused the comfort of a typical redemption arc, as the film subverts expectations to authentically capture the confusion and terror of refugee experience.

While one might be tempted to pin ‚ÄúTransit‚Äù as another film that depicts the horrors of war and genocide, its refusal to follow the ‚Äúnever again‚Äù narrative sets it apart. The horrendous acts of the past are not just frightening events that are now behind us: They are happening now, while the world turns a blind eye.

Thus the film is not simply a reflection of past atrocities. It reminds us of current events, possible futures, and above all, to remain vigilant as history repeats itself yet again.

Dorothy Calabro is a Ph.D. student in the Literature, Media, and Culture program at Florida State University.

IF YOU GO

What: ‚ÄúTransit‚Äù presented by the Tallahassee Film Society

When: 6 p.m. Friday, 7 p.m. Saturday, 5 p.m. Sunday

Where: All Saints Cinema, 918-¬Ω Railroad Ave.

Cost: $10, $7 for TFS members and students

Title: 5 outstanding Fort Myers and Cape Coral taco restaurants worth finding for Cinco de Mayo
Summary:
The best tacos in Fort Myers and Cape Coral? JLB has you covered for Cinco de Mayo and every other taco-loving day of the year.

I could get into the completely Americanized theater that is Cinco de Mayo. Or I could look at it as yet another acceptable reason to celebrate one of the greatest foods on earth: Tacos.

I'm going with the latter.

CONSIDER SUBSCRIBING TODAY: Help support local journalism

And if you're in Fort Myers, North Fort Myers or Cape Coral, these are five of my current favorites for sating even the most serious taco craving.

ARCHIVES: Jean Le Boeuf: The Great SWFL Taqueria Trek 2017

Tacos San Miguel

I can say with certainty, these are the best tacos you‚Äôll ever eat from a food trailer parked behind a 7-Eleven. Or from a narrow dining room tucked into an invisible corner of a Del Prado Boulevard strip mall. Tacos San Miguel now has two locations, and they're equally offbeat. But the food? That's a different story. The carnitas are slow-braised, the lengua finely chopped, the salsas hand-made, the onions grilled till tender. Put it all together and: Yum.

(1524 Pine Island Road, Cape Coral; 645-1993; find it on Facebook)

MORE: Tacos San Miguel II hurts so good ‚Äî JLB review

Moderation isn't a thing at Tacos San Miguel II in Cape Coral. (Photo: Special to The News-Press)

Taco Vazquez II

A handmade tortilla is completely unmistakable: the rough edges, the slight thickness, the delicate chew. A handmade tortilla at a gas-station taqueria is completely unexpected. Unless you‚Äôre at Taco Vazquez II (sadly, the original, in an Estero gas station, has closed). Tucked into a nearby Chevron gas station in San Carlos Park, Taco Vazquez II defies convenience-store norms. The food is fresh, scratch-made, deeply flavored and dirt-cheap. It‚Äôs hardly fancy, but it‚Äôs completely, unmistakably good.

(18960 S. Tamiami Trail, San Carlos Park; 239-440-8252)

A trio of tacos with handmade tortillas from Taco Vazquez in Estero. (Photo: Special to The News-Press)

Taqueria Celaya

I have a thing, it seems, for gas-station tacos. Celaya sits in a back corner of the Discount Tabacco & Beer (catchy name) on Crystal Drive in The Villas neighborhood of south Fort Myers. Amid rows of glass pipes and beef jerky are these outstanding tacos. They come heaped with chopped-up meats and finished with a sprinkle of cilantro and onions. There are tamales, too, steamy and tender. And empanadas with a puffy chew to their hand-pinched crusts. It's not the gas station that brings me back to Taqueria Celaya, it's everything else.

(2101 Crystal Drive, south Fort Myers, inside the Marathon gas station; 239-895-5608)

MORE: Fuel up: 5 gas station food finds in Fort Myers, Estero, Naples

A pair of al pastor tacos finished with cilantro and onions from Taqueria Celaya located in the Marathon gas station on Crystal Drive in south Fort Myers. (Photo: Annabelle Tometich/The News-Press)

Super Tacos

Super Tacos: Fast and Fresh. Those five words are plastered to a neon orange and green building that works hard to grab the attention of the cars whirring by on Pine Island Road. Those willing to slow down are deliciously rewarded. Super Tacos crafts giant beautiful burritos, unmistakably fresh salsas and stunning gorditas ‚Äî tender cornmeal patties stuffed with fajita steak, chicken, barbacoa. But its tacos, oh man its tacos. There are Taco Bell-ish tacos and fish tacos and more authentic tacos finished with house sauces, cilantro and onions. Super Tacos has tacos for all. They are indeed fast and fresh, and, most importantly, they are oh so super.

(1771 Many Road, North Fort Myers; 239-652-0351; supertacos.net)

Steak and chicken tacos from Super Tacos in North Fort Myers. (Photo: Andrea Melendez/The News-Press/USA Today)

Taquizza

Man, where to start? There are the thick, messy tortas made on locally baked bread, and the milky from-scratch horchata dusted with cinnamon. There's the steamy pozole, the hot sauces, the incredibly nice people who work here ever-smiling. Taquizza is merely a stone's throw from Super Tacos, yet I love its tacos just as much. They come on springy, house-made tortillas piled with tender carnitas, tinga, barbacoa. Where to start at Taquizza? Anywhere is just fine.

(70 Pine Island Road, North Fort Myers; 997-1686; facebook.com/taquizzafortmyers)

MORE: Thanksgiving meals served to first responders, homeless at Taquizza

A carne asada taco with cilantro, fried onions and lime from Taquizza in North Fort Myers. (Photo: The News-Press file photo)

Jean Le Boeuf is the pseudonym used by a local food lover who dines at restaurants anonymously and without warning, with meals paid for by The News-Press or Naples Daily News. Follow the critic at facebook.com/jeanleboeufswfl or @JeanLeBoeuf on Twitter and Instagram.

Address: 2442 Dr Martin Luther King Jr Blvd, Fort Myers, FL 33901, USA

Title: Thieves rob lunch truck owner of cash, snacks in southwest Miami-Dade
Summary:
Themetrius Dorsey, 18, of Miami, is accused of robbing a lunch truck owner in southwest Miami-Dade.

MIAMI-DADE COUNTY, Fla. - One man has been arrested and two others remain on the loose after a lunch truck owner was robbed of cash and snacks in southwest Miami-Dade, authorities said.

The incident was reported around 5:40 p.m. Monday outside the victim's home in the area of Southwest 123rd Drive and 200th Street.

According to an arrest report, the victim was cleaning his lunch truck when he was approached by three people who were all armed with semi-automatic handguns.

Police said Themetrius Dorsey, 18, of Miami, and his two accomplices took the victim's wallet, which contained $200, his cellphone and $450 in cash from the right front pocket of his pants.

According to the arrest report, the victim was held up at gunpoint by Dorsey and another thief while the third person searched his truck.

Police said the thieves took snacks from the truck before fleeing from the scene headed east.

The victim called authorities and Miami-Dade police spotted Dorsey, but he fled from officers, authorities said.

Police said he was eventually apprehended in the backyard of a home in the area of Southwest 121st Avenue and 196th Terrace.

Dorsey faces charges of armed robbery and armed burglary. Police are still searching for the two other people involved in the incident.

Anyone with further information is asked to call Miami-Dade Crime Stoppers at 305-471-8477.

Copyright 2019 by WPLG Local10.com - All rights reserved.
Address: 3401 W Hallandale Beach Blvd, Pembroke Park, FL 33023, USA

Title: Hummingbird returns every year to visit man who nursed him back to health
Summary:
Hummingbird returns every year to visit man who nursed him back to health

A Georgia man has a yearly visit from a bird he rescued four years ago.Mike Cardenaz told WRDW that though you might not guess it by looking at him, he's a huge animal lover. The tattooed former SWAT officer is currently helping an injured chipmunk recover. ‚ÄúThat's what people call me, Dr. Doolittle,‚Äù said Cardenaz.He keeps flowers on his front porch that attract hummingbirds. Four years ago, Cardenaz came across one that needed help. ‚ÄúSeveral of his feathers in his wings were broken off and he couldn't take flight,‚Äù said Cardenaz.He named him Buzz and nursed him back to health with Pedialyte and sugar.‚ÄúI had to wait until he molted, and regrew new wings. That was 8 weeks. And he became a part of the family,‚Äù said Cardenaz.Eventually Buzz got his strength back.‚ÄúHe would fly around the yard and come back when he got exhausted because that was his comfort zone until he finally took off for the winter. And he's been coming back for the last four years,‚Äù said Cardenaz.How does he know it's the same hummingbird?‚ÄúRandom hummingbirds don't land in your hand,‚Äù said Cardenaz.Buzz was about a week or two later than normal, causing Cardenaz to worry. ‚ÄúI was kind of worried about him and I was on the front porch, sweeping off the front porch and I felt something zoom around my head. I stood on the front porch, put my hand out, and he landed on my hand,‚Äù said Cardenaz.

A Georgia man has a yearly visit from a bird he rescued four years ago.

Mike Cardenaz told WRDW that though you might not guess it by looking at him, he's a huge animal lover. The tattooed former SWAT officer is currently helping an injured chipmunk recover.

Advertisement

‚ÄúThat's what people call me, Dr. Doolittle,‚Äù said Cardenaz.

He keeps flowers on his front porch that attract hummingbirds. Four years ago, Cardenaz came across one that needed help.

‚ÄúSeveral of his feathers in his wings were broken off and he couldn't take flight,‚Äù said Cardenaz.

He named him Buzz and nursed him back to health with Pedialyte and sugar.

‚ÄúI had to wait until he molted, and regrew new wings. That was 8 weeks. And he became a part of the family,‚Äù said Cardenaz.

Eventually Buzz got his strength back.

‚ÄúHe would fly around the yard and come back when he got exhausted because that was his comfort zone until he finally took off for the winter. And he's been coming back for the last four years,‚Äù said Cardenaz.

How does he know it's the same hummingbird?

‚ÄúRandom hummingbirds don't land in your hand,‚Äù said Cardenaz.

Buzz was about a week or two later than normal, causing Cardenaz to worry.

‚ÄúI was kind of worried about him and I was on the front porch, sweeping off the front porch and I felt something zoom around my head. I stood on the front porch, put my hand out, and he landed on my hand,‚Äù said Cardenaz.

Title: Man accused of throwing cinder block at vehicle as ‚Äòprank'
Summary:
- A Palm Bay man was arrested over the weekend, accused of throwing a cinder block at a moving car.

The incident happened Friday on Jupiter Boulevard, near Garvey Road.

Robert Pearce said he had his two daughters in the car with him, when someone in an oncoming car threw a piece of cinder block at his SUV.

‚ÄúAs I start to approach them, I see this chunk of debris come flying out of the car through the headlights,‚Äù Pearce said. ‚ÄúThen, WHAM! Hit the truck, broke into a couple of pieces.‚Äù

Pearce followed the car until the driver pulled onto Malabar Road, nearly hitting a motorcyclist, according to police.

Two passengers in the car told police Kadeem Tomlinson, 20, who was sitting behind the driver, collected a cinder block before getting in the car and stated he was going to throw it at a random car in the roadway as a ‚Äòprank.‚Äô

Kadeem is facing charges for criminal mischief and throwing a deadly missile.
Address: 35 Skyline Dr, Lake Mary, FL 32746, USA

Title: Man accused of using ex's Facebook account to send explicit images
Summary:
ST. MARYS, Ga. - St. Marys police said they arrested a man who illegally took over his ex-girlfriend's Facebook account then used the account to transmit nude images of her online.

Henry Powell, 34, is charged with transmitting sexually explicit images, tampering with evidence, obstruction of justice and computer trespass.

According to the St. Marys Police Department, Powell illegally gained access to his ex-girlfriend's Facebook account, blocked her from accessing the account and then used the account to link to her Facebook Messenger where he accessed several explicit images of her that were intended for private use.

According to a preliminary police report, Powell admitted to sending those images via Facebook Messenger to her relatives. It is only the preliminary report, which means more charges are pending.

Attorney Randy Reep is not affiliated with the case, but said Powell is accused of illegally accessing the victim‚Äôs social media account, impeding her from using the account and stealing something that belongs to her.

"That is a type of trespass," Reep said.

Reep said criminal computer activity is nothing new, but "it is growing very fast."

"We see more things like the standard revenge porn," he said.

Chris Hamer, a computer security expert, said it is very hard to hack into someone's social media account, but not always.

"Somebody that has been in a previous relationship, there is a good probability that passwords have been shared, devices have been used. Something may be cached," Hamer said.

To prevent this from happening after a bad breakup, Hamer suggests eliminating account access to all devices that used the account and then change the password.

He added: "If you don‚Äôt want naked pictures of you on the internet, don‚Äôt have naked pictures on any device that‚Äôs connected to the internet. It‚Äôs the simplest way to avoid it."

In the St. Marys case, according to Hamer, the victim could go after Powell in civil court because the private pictures are copyrighted material that belongs to the victim.

CITRUS COUNTY, Fla. (WFLA) ‚Äì A man is facing charges after leading troopers on a pursuit through multiple counties and firing rounds at them on Sunday.

According to the Florida Highway Patrol, the Citrus County Sheriff‚Äôs Office contacted FHP and requested assistance in the pursuit of a stolen Ford truck on SR-44. Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. (Source: FHP)

The driver, identified as Travis Lovett, 22, of Bushnell, had attempted to run over two deputies during the pursuit.

Several FHP troopers responded and located Lovett at US-41 and Kabrick Road. They started pursuing his vehicle.

The pursuit continued into Hernando County and east on CR-476.

Lovett allegedly shot three rounds from a handgun at the troopers and one bullet struck a trooper‚Äôs windshield.

The pursuit continued east on CR-476 into Sumter County, where troopers were able to complete a PIT maneuver, causing the stolen vehicle to overturn multiple times.

Lovett was ejected from the vehicle.

Troopers secured Lovett and requested medical assistance.

He was flown to Bayonet Point and then taken to Tampa General Hospital, where he remains.

Charges against Lovett are pending from the FHP and the Citrus sheriff‚Äôs office.

Title: Man burned alive angry that man who did it was given plea deal
Summary:
JACKSONVILLE, Fla. - Anthony Bagg is angry that the man who set him on fire in 2015 and was initially charged with attempted murder was allowed by the State Attorney‚Äôs Office to plead guilty to a lesser charge.

Late last month, Jason Wilson, 44, pleaded guilty to a reduced charge of aggravated battery and accepted a seven-year prison sentence. The three years, four months Wilson has spent in jail since his arrest count toward the completion of that sentence.

Bagg said Wilson, pictured left, took everything from him on Sept. 20, 2015. Bagg was playing the video game "Call of Duty" when he said Wilson, an acquaintance, knocked on his Sandalwood door, came inside and lit him on fire.

‚ÄúWhen I looked up, all I see is fire coming towards my face,‚Äù said Bagg.

Bagg said the room caught fire, too, and much of the house was destroyed. The family dog died from smoke inhalation.

Bagg remembers getting into an ambulance, and the next thing he remembers is waking up in the burn unit a Shands Hospital in Gainesville. He had been in a coma for four months.

Bagg suffered third-degree burns on most of his body and couldn‚Äôt move his arms or legs. He underwent a series of skin grafts. He still has internal injuries and his body is scarred for life.

‚ÄúIt just took everything away. It literally made me relive all the phases of my life over again,‚Äù said Bagg.

Bagg asked prosecutors with the State Attorney‚Äôs office not to give Wilson a plea deal.

"[The prosecutor] was like, ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs too many different stories. Things aren‚Äôt adding up, so it‚Äôs pretty much just going to end up your word against his word,'" Bagg said. "I got set on fire. He took my looks, my everything away from me. Everything I care most about, well, except my kids."

Copyright 2019 by WJXT News4Jax - All rights reserved.
Address: 4 Broadcast Pl, Jacksonville, FL 32207, USA

Title: Milton man, 22, dies in pedestrian crash
Summary:
SANTA ROSA COUNTY ‚Äî A 22-year-old man died Sunday night after being struck by a truck while walking along State Road 10 near U.S. Highway 90.

Alex Elks of Milton was walking east on State Road 10 in the eastbound right travel lane at approximately 10:50 p.m., according to a press release from Florida Highway Patrol.

Tristan Hughes, 20 of Jay, was driving a Ford F150 east in the same lane as the pedestrian, the press release said. Hughes failed to see Elks walking on a portion of the road and hit him.

Elks was propelled in a southeasterly direction onto the property of a car detailing business on U.S. Highway 90. He was taken to Santa Rosa Medical. Florida Highway Patrol was unclear as to whether Elks died before or at the hospital.

Hughes suffered no injuries, the press release said. Alcohol was not a related factor to the crash.

No charges were listed.
Address: 2 Eglin Pkwy NE, Fort Walton Beach, FL 32548, USA
